content:
Let f:C→Df: C \to Df:C→D be a limit preserving functor between complete categories.
Example A4.1.10 from the Elephant shows that the induced functor f∗:[Dop,Set]→[Cop,Set]f^* : [D^{op}, Set] \to [C^{op}, Set]f∗:[Dop,Set]→[Cop,Set] has a left exact left adjoint. It does so only assuming f:C→Df :C \to Df:C→D is a cartesian functor between cartesian categories, so I was hoping to leverage my stronger assumptions and conclude Lan⁡f\operatorname{Lan}_fLanf​ actually preserves all limits.
I'm not at ease with the kind of arguments employed by Johnstone so I don't really know if they straightforwardly generalize to my case.
Screenshot-from-2021-01-01-13-04-44.png
Are CCC and DDD large categories? If so I don't see why the left Kan extension should exist in the first place (let alone preserve limits).
Isn't the left exact left adjoint Lanf\mathrm{Lan}_fLanf​?
Yes.
I suppose the point is that the adjoint may not exist unless CCC and DDD are small.

I'm not very good at this stuff, so I'll just say some guesses to keep the conversation rolling. The category of presheaves on CCC is the free cocompletion of CCC when CCC is small, and this is another way of saying that any functor f:C→Df: C \to Df:C→D between small categories extends to a cocontinuous functor from [Cop,Set][C^{op},Set][Cop,Set] to [Dop,Set][D^{op},Set][Dop,Set], namely Lanf:[Cop,Set]→[Dop,Set]Lan_f: [C^{op},Set] \to [D^{op},Set]Lanf​:[Cop,Set]→[Dop,Set]. But this may not work when CCC is large - I believe the problem is more with CCC being large than DDD being large. And as Reid Barton hinted, complete categories are large unless they are preorders. So Matteo's question is problematic unless he's willing to assume CCC is a preorder.
How about this substitute, then? Instead of assuming CCC and DDD have all small limits, assume they are small categories with all JJJ-limits where JJJ is any chosen set of diagrams (not class, set).

Suppose f:C→Df: C \to Df:C→D preserves all JJJ-limits.

Question: does Lanf:[Cop,Set]→[Dop,Set]Lan_f : [C^{op},Set] \to [D^{op},Set]Lanf​:[Cop,Set]→[Dop,Set] preserve JJJ-limits?

My guess is yes, but I'm not very good at this stuff.
Oh right. Or he's in a constructive setting where that fact about preorders is wrong.
I think this is probably related to the notion of a sound doctrine (page itself is not helpful, but has useful links), though I never properly understood this stuff.

If JJJ is the collection of all κ\kappaκ-small diagrams (κ\kappaκ a regular cardinal), then the same sort of argument as in Johnstone would work. For JJJ the collection of finite discrete categories you can argue directly: products commute with colimits in each argument so you can reduce to the case of representables, which is true by definition.
CCC and DDD are small preorders in my case, yes. EDIT: Oh, I see why you're discussing completeness. I put it in my first post without thinking about Freyd's result.
However my issue is not really with the existence of Lanf\mathrm{Lan}_fLanf​, but with its continuity
I know it preserves finite limits when fff does, can one extend this to small limits?

Okay, preorders can be complete and small, so all our worries dissolve. Then my guess is just yes, if CCC and DDD are complete small preorders and f:C→Df: C \to Df:C→D preserves all small limits then so does LanfLan_fLanf​. But my belief is based on my feel for how presheaves work; I'm not good at proving this stuff.

Can you elaborate on that feel? :thinking: Above you mentioned the universal property of small presheaves, but that gives cocontinuity of Lanf\mathrm{Lan}_fLanf​, right? Why shall I expect continuity?

I think this will work for posets:
if f:C→Df : C \to Df:C→D preserves all small limits (equivalently, all meets), then it has a left adjoint functor.
Further, the functor that sends a category to its presheaf topos, and a functor to its left Kan extension, is a 2-functor, and as such it preserves adjunctions. So the left Kan extension Lanf\mathrm{Lan}_fLanf​ has a left adjoint as well. More precisely, its left adjoint is given by Lang\mathrm{Lan}_gLang​, where ggg is the left adjoint of fff.

That's a super-nice argument, taking advantage of the "dream world" of preorders, where the adjoint functor theorem loses all its technicalities: a functor between preorders has a left adjoint iff its continuous.
Mmmh it feels like too many adjunctions between the presheaves categories :thinking:

For what little it's worth, @Matteo Capucci, here was my intuition. When you embed a small category C into its category of presheaves you are "freely throwing in colimits". So colimits that used to be colimits in C no longer are, unless there's a damn good reason they have to be ("absolute colimits"). However, limits in C are still limits inside the category of presheaves.

Because we're "freely throwing in colimits" when we take the preseheaf category, we can extend any functor f:C→Df: C \to Df:C→D to a colimit-preserving preserving functor between presheaves, and that's LanfLan_fLanf​. But because taking presheaves doesn't mess with limits, LanfLan_fLanf​ should preserve any limits that fff did.

That last sentence is a total hand-wave, not an argument. I guess the rigorous portion of it is that if fff preserves limits of some sort, LanfLan_fLanf​ must preserve that sort of limit on representables. But why should it do so for all presheaves?

If I had to try to create a proof, I'd try to use the fact that all presheaves are colimits of representables, and do some commuting of limits and colimits... but I don't know if this works.

Someone like @Todd Trimble could settle these questions in his sleep.
But Jens' argument is so slick even I can understand it. It does the job for preorders.

John Baez said:

For what little it's worth, Matteo Capucci, here was my intuition. When you embed a small category C into its category of presheaves you are "freely throwing in colimits". So colimits that used to be colimits in C no longer are, unless there's a damn good reason they have to be ("absolute colimits"). However, limits in C are still limits inside the category of presheaves.

Because we're "freely throwing in colimits" when we take the preseheaf category, we can extend any functor f:C→Df: C \to Df:C→D to a colimit-preserving preserving functor between presheaves, and that's LanfLan_fLanf​. But because taking presheaves doesn't mess with limits, LanfLan_fLanf​ should preserve any limits that fff did.

That last sentence is a total hand-wave, not an argument. I guess the rigorous portion of it is that if fff preserves limits of some sort, LanfLan_fLanf​ must preserve that sort of limit on representables. But why should it do so for all presheaves?

If I had to try to create a proof, I'd try to use the fact that all presheaves are colimits of representables, and do some commuting of limits and colimits... but I don't know if this works.

I see. Then there's should be an easy proof by coend calculus then :thinking: I'll try fiddling around.

Jens Hemelaer said:

I think this will work for posets:
if f:C→Df : C \to Df:C→D preserves all small limits (equivalently, all meets), then it has a left adjoint functor.
Further, the functor that sends a category to its presheaf topos, and a functor to its left Kan extension, is a 2-functor, and as such it preserves adjunctions. So the left Kan extension Lanf\mathrm{Lan}_fLanf​ has a left adjoint as well. More precisely, its left adjoint is given by Lang\mathrm{Lan}_gLang​, where ggg is the left adjoint of fff.

Also I'm now convinced by this. Neat!
I don't think this "commuting limits and colimits" approach will work for a general JJJ--if you take something like a pullback over a colimit, you can't easily relate that to a colimit of pullbacks.
Yeah, I had a feeling of desperation right around when I suggested that. It was helpful for me to make explicit my intuitions because then I could see the huge hole.
